newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: EU leaders to ponder progress of treaty talks.
newsitem.headline: EU leaders to ponder progress of treaty talks.

text.p: When EU leaders meet in Dublin this week to review progress on a new EU treaty, they will find a rough outline of what is expected to emerge from the talks but that little else has been agreed, officials said on Tuesday.
Heads of state and government from the 15 European Union nations are to meet in the Irish capital on Saturday to discuss the bloc's preparations for the next century.
At issue is the so-called inter-governmental conference (IGC), a treaty-writing excercise designed to get the EU in shape to handle an influx of new members from eastern Europe and the Mediterranean.
The talks began in March, and to date have generally followed a plan laid out for them first by the Italians, who held the EU presidency until June, and then by the Irish, who took over.
This has entailed systematic discussions of various areas to be covered by the review, collecting countries' views, and recently, drafting potential treaty language.
But no firm agreements have been reached -- only what Dutch European Affairs Minister Michiel Patijn, one of the negotiators, calls "the contours" of a future treaty.

"If you schedule a conference for 15 months, you can't expect (too much progress) after six," Patijn told Reuters in a recent interview. Most negotiators expect a frienzied phase of horse-trading next year just before the IGC's scheduled end.
But others have become stingingly critical of the pace of the talks, charging that the IGC has got nowhere and needs a big boost from the EU leaders on Saturday.

"We have spent over a year going around in circles like whirling dervishes...and we have not made even half a centimetre of progress," French Foreign Minister Herve de Charette said on Sunday. He was including preparatory talks in his time-frame.
What the leaders will find on Saturday is that the areas that the new treaty is likely to cover have been identified, but that specific pacts remain a long way off.
The new treaty is widely expected to include a so-called employment chapter, designed to put job creation at the top of the EU's agenda. This is supported by a majority of states, negotiators say.

It is also likely to build on previous pledges to create a strong pan-European foreign policy. There is widespread support for a new forward planning unit to be created and for some kind of senior figure to be appointed as coordinator.
There is also general acceptance that EU institutions and procedures will have to be changed to accommodate new members.
But there is no agreement on how this is to be done, with Britain, in particular, holding out against any loss of sovereignty in the name of efficiency.
Small countries are also fighting moves to cut the number of EU commissioners or their role as EU presidents.
Overall, negotiators say, the most significant new proposal may be to incorporate so-called flexibility into the treaty -- a concept allowing some countries to integrate faster or deeper than others.
"Flexibility may suit those who want to press ahead, and it may suit those who do not want to join them," Irish negotiator Noel Dorr said.
